Abstract: This paper reviews recent advancements in the field of partial identification, focusing on methodologies that leverage set identification, bounds, treatment effects, shape restrictions, and optimizing behavior. Partial identification approaches have gained prominence for their ability to provide robust inferences in the presence of model uncertainty and data limitations. We explore how these techniques have been applied to estimate treatment effects, offering a framework that accommodates a wide range of assumptions and data structures. The discussion highlights the role of shape restrictions and optimizing behavior in tightening the bounds of identified sets, thereby enhancing the precision of causal inferences. Through a synthesis of recent literature, this review underscores the potential of partial identification methods to address complex empirical questions, offering insights into their application across various domains of economic and social research.
